bioghist.p: Edward G. Brame, Jr. (1927-2002) was the president of the CECON Group, a chemical and engineering consulting firm. He and several friends founded the company in 1985. Prior to that he worked for the DuPont Company for 27 years. A respected and accomplished spectroscopist, Brame was the editor of Applied Spectroscopy Reviews for 30 years, editor in chief of Practical Spectroscopy for 22 years, and associate editor of Applied Spectroscopy for five years. Brame was interested in paranormal phenomena, and his work in spectroscopy intersected with his investigations in parapsychology.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Brame's personal and professional papers. Materials include: a few documents from Brame's youth; family photographs; records of his service in the Navy; his dissertation, entitled "Infrared Study of Some Complexes of the Platinum Metals and Related Compounds" (1957, University of Wisconsin); a small album of wedding photos; documents from a 1983 National Academy of Sciences/National Research Council-sponsored visit to the USSR; research notebooks and spiritual journals; psychic studies articles; documents from the Center for Frontier Sciences at Temple University; programs and other printed material from the Federation of Analytical Chemistry and Spectroscopy Societies (FACSS); drafts and reprints of articles authored or co-authored by Brame on infrared spectroscopy, nuclear quadropole resonance spectroscopy, and other topics; miscellaneous research notes; certificates and awards; and various artifacts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
